Portal 2 is leaps and bounds better than Portal, though Portal should absolutely be played before Portal 2, for both story and gameplay reasons. Portal 2 has some of the best writing, and design of any game I've ever played, it's a classic for a reason. Portal 2 will make you think, and feel, and even laugh. It has creative and interesting concepts that over arch a plot that has many twists and turns. If you haven't played the portal games I would recommend them as they provide some of the most unique gameplay and writing that a puzzle game can provide. 9/10 it looks good while being both difficult and fun.
great game! recommend it to everyone!

Simplismente sensacional. Se você gostou de Portal 1, pode ter certeza que vai adorar a sequência e se você não gostou, tem grandes chances de curtir também porque esse jogo é foda. Jogo é bem fluido, bons puzzles, humor ácido, momentos de tensão e revelações sobre a história dos personagens. Tudo isso combinado com uma boa trilha sonora que aparece em partes cruciais do jogo.
Recomendo.

If you dont have this game then WHAT ARE YOU DOING

Gameplay:
The Gameplay is super good and the portal mechanics make a lot of sense and you dont end up thinking "well that makes no sense" basicly everything can go through a portal exept portals because that would be overpowered and ruin the game but. the puzzles make sense but there are some points in the game that are just "look around until you find something to shoot at" and i hate that because it doesnt really take skill or thinking. the graphics are great and this game is just great

Replayability:
This game is not really designed for replaying but its still fun and i have beated the maingame 2-3 times and the Co-op 1 time because i liked the game so much

Co-op:
The co-op is just as good as the normal game and the diference is that you each (2 players) have a portal gun with 2 portals in each so there can be 4 portals so it is kind of diferent but if you get the game then beat the singelplayer first and then play the co-op with a freind (it will make most sense)

The Story:
I know that there is a story i just have not figured it out because i only own portal 2 and not the orginal portal because ther is more content in this game (im 99% percent sure)
Almost died, almost died again, got revenge, got betrayed, learned a lot of funny science and got revenge again after almost dying at least 40 more times
The coolest single player game I've played so far. I like Portal 1 almost as much. Still haven't even played the multiplayer
great game but the puzzles can take a while to figure out

Eines der besten Spiele überhaupt!

Als es damals rausgekommen ist, habe ich es direkt durchgespielt.

Heute habe ich es nach langer Zeit erneut durchgespielt. Und es ist immernoch eines meiner Lieblingsspiele.
Kann es nur jedem empfehlen, der ein bisschen schwarzen Humor mit Puzzle-Spiel verbinden will.

Extremely tedious puzzles, but a hillarious story and genious voice-acting. This game, along with Portal 1, are such great games and are definetly worth playing through. With Portal 2's co-op mode, you can mess around with your friends and have a load of fun. I really do hope they will make Portal 3 soon

I mean, it's Portal 2.  Honestly this is a hall-of-fame type game for me.  Creative, addicting, infinitely replayable.  Now if only I could actually give Cave Johnson the killer puzzle design he's looking for in the multiverse...

Portal 2 is a worthy sequel of the original. While it naturally becomes more complex in both gameplay and story, it does not grow beyond its scope and still remains a rather tight, small story within the labs of Aperture which keeps with the spirit of the first game. The writing remains stellar, with Ellen McLain as GLaDOS starting out the game with her hilarious brand of passive-aggressive assaults on you. Her voice in this game is more expressive and emotional than in the last, which is in line with the game's attempts to humanise her as a character. Other voice talents--including Stephen Merchant as Wheatley, J.K. Simmons as Cave Johnson and Dee Bradley Baker as Atlas, P-body and the defective turrets--all provide stunning performances that are all hilarious in their own way.

If you liked Portal for its classic gags such as the cake and the companion cube will find Portal 2 to their liking, as well. You'll find your repeatable gags in the form of combustable lemons, Machiavellian morons. birds and cores. Don't think that the only draw of Portal 2 is in its humour, though. While it does not, to me, surpass the first game in offering a sense of oppressive and suffocating isolation, it instead provides many different backdrops which each have distinct atmospheres that can really stick with players if they choose to just pause and appreciate them. The overgrown test chambers as well as the ruins of old Aperture are both very atmospheric.

The music in this game is also really damn good--good enough that I bought the album to listen to when I'm out and about. I find standouts in the Friendly Faith Plate and Cara Mia Addio, which offer varying tones of violent and loud machinery to a beautiful piece that makes your heart get all fluttery listening. Of course, I couldn't mention the music in this game without mentioning Exile Vilify, the track by the National that appears on some of the radios in Rattman's dens. The song is beautiful, and also earned its place in my phone's storage. 

The pacing of the game and the introduction of new gameplay mechanics seems well thought out in that I never found myself growing bored or losing attention and going into autopilot. Of course, since this is a puzzle game that isn't randomly generated, subsequent playthroughs do lose some of the magic in that you'll know the solution to all the tests and can kinda just start to coast through the game. Fear not, however, as Valve has remedied this with the introduction of the Perpetual Testing Initiative! Now you can turn to the community for more creatively made tests from fellow players like you! Of course, if you fancy getting your mad AI complex on, you can take to making some tests yourself and putting them out there for others to pit their wit against. This even comes with its own story, of sorts, in the form of audio that begins at the start of tests from a smorgasbord of alternate universe Cave Johnsons. If you thought one of these guys was mad, just wait until you're listening to him across several universes. It is choc full of hilarious stuff and really makes you excited to get to the next test.

Portal 2, unlike the first game, is now also a co-op! This isn't like the common co-op fare of "single-player campaign but now there's more of you"; Portal 2's co-op campaign is its own beast, complete with tests designed for two and a story which takes place after the events of the single-player story with the aforementioned Atlas and P-body as the stars. The tests are well designed and the characters of Atlas and P-body are given plenty of life, whether through Dee Bradley Baker's performances or the variety of emotes you are given over the course of the campaign which really add that extra bit of fun and flavour to the gameplay. Of course, during this campaign, GLaDOS is once again presiding over the tests which means that you get to hear a lot more humorous snark from her.

Overall, I'd say that Portal 2 is an exceptional sequel that takes the seed of the first game and waters it into a beautiful, blooming flower. More puzzles, more humour, more story, yet never overstepping itself and becoming too much. This game is a treat and, unlike any other franchise they've made, this sequel makes me really sad that Valve can't count to three.
